awd_titl_txt: Effect of Molecular Structure on the Atmospheric Oxidation of Organic Compounds and Aerosol Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
The overall objective of the project is to conduct experimental and modeling studies to achieve an improved understanding and quantitative description of the effects of the molecular structure of organic compounds on their atmospheric oxidation products and their tendency for the products to form aerosols. Atmospheric gaseous and particulate compounds can affect air quality, visibility, climate, and human and ecosystem health. This project will provide new data on organic oxidation products and mechanisms, which should be applicable to many other atmospheric reactions because of the similarities in basic reaction pathways.

Experiments will be conducted in large volume, inert Teflon environmental chambers under simulated atmospheric conditions. Chemical reaction products present in the gas and particle phases will be identified and quantified using real-time and offline methods that employ various combinations of appropriate analytical techniques such as chromatography, spectroscopy, and mass spectrometry. Specific experiments are designed to quantify the effects of linear and branched molecular structures and oxygenated functional groups on chemical reaction pathways. Results will be incorporated into a detailed chemical reaction model, which will be evaluated and further improved by comparing simulations with measured gas- and particle-phase products formed from the oxidation of a set of atmospherically representative alkanes, alkenes, and oxygenated compounds, under both polluted and clean air conditions.

The provision of support of a graduate student along with activities intended to contribute to public understanding of science of air quality and climate issues are mentioned project activities. The models that will be improved and evaluated as a result of this project are used in laboratory, regional, and global simulations, which are widely used to evaluate potential effects of gases and particles on visibility, human health, ecosystems, and climate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The results of this research project improve current understanding of atmospheric chemical reactions by which hydrocarbons and oxygenated compounds (collectively referred to as volatile organic compounds or VOCs) that are emitted to the atmosphere from anthropogenic and natural sources become oxidized to form new products. In particular, detailed information on the identity and amounts of reaction products, especially those that can condense to form submicron size aerosol particles, were obtained from laboratory studies. Experiments were conducted in large Teflon chambers, where organic compounds were reacted with OH radicals, the major atmospheric oxidant, under conditions that simulated those that occur in the clean or polluted atmosphere. Products that were formed as gases or particles were sampled and analyzed using methods including gas and liquid chromatography (which separate complex chemical mixtures into their individual components) and mass spectrometry (which identifies compounds based on their chemical fingerprint). The results were used to identify and determine rates of key reaction pathways that are common to all gaseous VOC oxidation processes, but which occur to a greater or lesser degree in a particular reaction depending on the structure of the molecule and atmospheric conditions. Understanding the relative importance of these pathways is critical to predicting the outcome of atmospheric reactions and aerosol particle formation, which influence regional and global climate, the hydrologic cycle, visibility, and human and environmental health. The experimental results and reaction mechanisms developed here will be used by scientists to develop computational air quality and climate models, which are used to predict the fates of organic compounds in the atmosphere, the effects of organic chemicals and aerosol particles on atmospheric composition and processes, and to develop air quality regulations. In addition to obtaining these scientific results, this project provided support for training the three Ph.D. and two M.S. chemistry students, and one undergraduate chemical engineering student, who conducted the research. As a result, they learned how to conduct scientific experiments, perform chemical synthesis and analysis, measure reaction rates, and develop atmospheric chemical reaction mechanisms. They also learned how to analyze and interpret data, write technical articles, and give oral presentations, skills that they can apply in almost any future job.Those who have graduated are now employed as research scientists or technical experts at Smith College, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, Aerodyne Research, Merck, Compounders International Analytical Laboratory, and VWR Scientific, and thus continuing to work in fields that make use of their scientific and technical skills.
